security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only TypeScript development guidelines and best practices. No executable code, no network access, no filesystem operations, and no external command execution. This is a documentation-only skill that provides coding standards for TypeScript projects.

content.value_statement: TypeScript projects often suffer from type safety issues, lax linting, and inconsistent code quality. This skill provides best practices, code patterns, and quality checklists to ensure robust, maintainable TypeScript code.
actual_capabilities: Enforce strict TypeScript configuration with strict mode enabled
Guide proper use of optional chaining and nullish coalescing operators
Provide TSDoc documentation templates for public APIs
Show error handling patterns with custom error classes and Result types
Recommend utility types like Partial, Pick, and Omit
Define code quality checklists for code review
limitations: Does not execute code or run type checking commands
Does not modify project configuration files automatically
Does not install or configure build tools or linters
Only provides guidance and best practices, not automated fixes

use_cases.title: React TypeScript Projects
use_cases.description: Set up type-safe React components with proper generics, memoization, and lazy loading patterns.

use_cases.title: Node.js API Development
use_cases.description: Build type-safe API handlers with proper error handling, validation, and async patterns.

use_cases.title: Shared TypeScript Libraries
use_cases.description: Create reusable utility types, type guards, and union types for shared codebases.

prompt_templates.title: Type a function
prompt_templates.prompt: Add proper TypeScript types to this function. Use type inference where obvious. Do not use any type. Add TSDoc comments for public APIs.

prompt_templates.title: Create error handler
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a proper error handling pattern for this function. Use a Result type with success and error states. Include custom error classes.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor to types
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this code to remove all any types. Use proper type definitions, type guards, or generics. Explain your type choices.

prompt_templates.title: Write type utility
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a TypeScript utility type for this use case. Use built-in utility types like Partial, Pick, or Omit as reference. Add TSDoc documentation.

output_examples.input: Create a type-safe function to fetch user data
output: Define a Result<T, E> type for success/error states
Create a custom ValidationError class extending Error
Use async/await with proper Promise<T> return types
Add TSDoc comments documenting parameters and return types

best_practices: Always enable strict mode in tsconfig.json for maximum type safety
Use type inference when the type is obvious from context to reduce redundancy
Document public APIs with TSDoc comments when intent is not clear from signature
anti_patterns: Using any type instead of proper type definitions
Using require() instead of ES module imports
Skipping error handling in async functions

faq.question: Does this skill work with JavaScript projects?
faq.answer: No. This skill is specific to TypeScript. Use JavaScript-specific skills for JS projects.

faq.question: What TypeScript versions are supported?
faq.answer: Supports TypeScript 3.0 and later. Best results with TypeScript 4.0+ for newer features.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my tsconfig.json?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance but does not modify project files automatically.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. This skill runs locally with no network access or external data transmission.

faq.question: Why am I getting type errors?
faq.answer: Ensure strict mode is enabled. Check that all variables have proper types. Use type guards for runtime type checking.

faq.question: How is this different from a linter?
faq.answer: A linter enforces syntax rules. This skill provides guidance on type design, patterns, and best practices for writing better TypeScript.
